bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Richard Foote, September 19, 1720

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Stafford County resident Richard Foote, September 19, 1720, to enclose copies of two of Micajah Perry's letters concerning Foote's business to show Foote what he (Carter) has been doing in Foote's behalf, and advising him that he probably will have to go to England "the next Shipping."

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Richard Foote, September 19, 1720

opener.dateline:
[Corotoman, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Sepr: 19th. 1720—
Mr. Richd. Foote——

div1.p:
I believe You are Impatient to L[earn] some
=thing of Yor. business to lett You see I have not bin wanting in
my part, herewith Send You Copys of two of Mr. Perrys Lettrs.
by wch. You'l See the Expectations I have of a larger Accot
of Yor. Affair in a Short time, as my Intelligence comes
to hand You Shall have Copys of It, I almost think Your
Friends will Genly. be of the opinion there will be a necess
=ity for Yor. going for Engd. the next Shipping, but the
next Lettrs. will be Yor. better Guid I conclude at present

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1720 July-1721 July, BR 227, Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens, San Marino, California. Printed: Wright. Letters of Robert Carter. . . . p. 45.
"Corotoman," the name of Robert Carter's home, the county, and the state have been added for clarity because the draft does not include any of them.

[1] Richard Foote (1666-1724) of Stafford County, nephew of Nicholas Hayward, developer of the Brent Town speculation in the Northern Neck Proprietary. Foote's father was one of Hayward's partners, and a successful merchant in London. The son lived in the Brent Town tract, and represented the owners in Virginia.
